item.title: Acct: The Ultimate Keyfinder
item.description:
Introduction link

In a production environment, it can be useful to know what each person is doing. This is particularly helpful when a mistake happens and nobody admits to it (yes, it happens). Novice hackers (aka script kiddies) who call themselves hackers because they’ve put a keylogger on a machine might also be interested in this. However, the purpose is obviously not the same.

Two commands are useful:

  • sa: obtains statistics on process launches
  • lastcomm: obtains a list of commands launched by users

item.title: ACL: Implementing NT-Style Permissions on Solaris
item.description:
Introduction link

With respect to a computer filesystem, an access control list (ACL) is a list of permissions attached to an object. An ACL specifies which users or system processes are granted access to objects, as well as what operations are allowed to be performed on given objects. In a typical ACL, each entry in the list specifies a subject and an operation (e.g. the entry (Alice, delete) on the ACL for file WXY gives Alice permission to delete file WXY).
